ORAL ANSWER TO QUESTION

POST OFFICE SAVINGS BANK
(Renovation of headquarters)


    1. Dr Tan Eng Liang asked the Minister for Communications (a) why the Post office Savings Bank spent a substantial amount of money on a major renovation of its headquarters at the site of the Registry of Vehicles, when the ROV site has already been earmarked for urban renewal; and (b) whether the Bank had obtained the concurrence of the relevant authorities such as the Land Office, Planning Department, Urban Renewal Department, etc., before embarking on the renovation.

    The Minister for Communications (Mr Yong Nyuk Lin): Mr Speaker, Sir, in 1970 when the Post Office Savings Bank was part of the Postal Department, it was decided to renovate its headquarters at Middle Road. At that

Column: 812

time, the area occupied by the Bank was about 6,000 sq. ft. To cope with the Bank's much increased business, it was necessary to expand the headquarters premises to alleviate congestion. Plans were finalised and funds voted for the project. At the end of 1970, the Bank was informed that the premises of the Registry of Vehicles in Middle Road were earmarked for re-development. Attempts were made to look for alternative accommodation for the Bank but suitable alternatives could not be found. Since it was considered that the Bank's continued use of the premises at Middle Road would be consistent with an urban renewal site, the Bank discussed with the Land Office the question of the purchase of the present building and site. In the discussions, the Commissioner of Lands indicated that the Bank's purchase of the site could only be considered if the Bank had firm plans for the building. The Commissioner of Lands was advised that detailed plans would be submitted in due course and that the Bank was

Column: 813

of the view the ROV complex at Middle Road would be suitable for the permanent headquarters of the Bank. The Bank also stated it would be interested in bidding for the whole ROV site when the latter was put up for re-development.

    On 1st January, 1972, the Bank became a statutory corporation and, as the need for accommodation was very acute, the Bank decided to proceed with renovation of the existing premises, and the Public Works Department was appointed to plan and execute the project. The Bank has assured the Commissioner of Lands that it does not intend seeking compensation if the building is subsequently demolished for re-development. The Bank also reiterated its interest in making a bid for the whole of the ROV site at Middle Road when the site is eventually available for re-development.

    When completed, the renovation costing approximately $266,000 will provide a total area of 10,500 sq. ft. If the Bank had tried in the open market to lease 10,500 sq. ft. of office space it would have to pay at least $120,000 per annum in rental. The ROV site at Middle Road is unlikely to be available for re-development for another three years. On this basis, even if the Bank's renovated building at Middle Road is pulled down for re-development in three years' time, there would still be a saving of about $94,000 to the Bank in renovating these existing premises rather than renting similar space on the open market.

MAIN AND DEVELOPMENT ESTIMATES OF SINGAPORE FOR THE

FINANCIAL YEAR 1ST APRIL, 1973 TO 31ST MARCH, 1974



    Order read for resumed consideration in Committee of Supply [3rd Allotted Day].

[Mr Speaker in the Chair]



2.37 p.m.

    Head 1001 -

    Mr Teong Eng Siong (Sembawang)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 1001 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 1001*. (* The same amendment also stood in the name of Mr P. Govindaswamy.)

    Sir, the National Sports Promotion Board, under the Ministry of Social Affairs, has the great responsibility of promoting sports. In recent years, the NSPB has done a lot in this respect. We have seen a lot of sports activities being carried out because of its efforts. For instance, under the auspices of NSPB last year, we conducted the first soccer competition among the various constituencies and also a basketball tournament. All these had been very successfully organised.

    However, the NSPB still has much to do to further improve sports activities. Firstly, since the responsibility of the NSPB is to promote and raise the standard of sports, it should go all out. For instance, in badminton we were well known in the past. But our standards have fallen "10,000 feet" down, and are still on the decline.

Column: 815

Every time our players took part in badminton competitions, they scored Nil. And for basketball or soccer matches too, the score was Nil; if it was not a chicken's egg, then it was a duck's egg. So as the NSPB is the nerve centre for sports promotion and as the Government has allocated large sums of money for this purpose to make our next generation a rugged one, the NSPB should live up to its name by not letting the people down, but give them confidence and hope that it will succeed.

    Sir, I would like to ask the Minister what has the NSPB done or achieved since its inception to raise the standard of sports. I regret to say that it has done nothing. It seems that the NSPB has not paid enough attention to promote sports and games in the last two years. It has only concentrated its attention on soccer. It appears that the NSPB has neglected to promote other sports like badminton, basket-ball, volley ball, field and track events, judo, and others. If it is so, I hope the Minister can rectify the matter.

    Sir, 1973 is undoubtedly an important year in our sports history because the SEAP Games will be held in Singapore in September this year. In addition to playing our part as the host country, we should also be able to ensure that our athletes put up a good performance in order to qualify for participation in these Games. I would therefore like to ask the Minister whether he has started any intensive training courses for our athletes to raise their standards.

    The other matter I wish to mention is that not enough publicity has been given to these Games. And very little has been done in respect of promotion or readiness for the Games. I feel it is not enough to have just a few posters pasted at the back of buses as advertisements. It is our glory that these Games will be held in our country. So the National Sports Promotion Board should publicise early so as to enable our people to be aware of this important event and the NSPB should also put in more effort to get the people to support the Games.

Column: 816



    Sir, I would like to give some suggestions to the Minister for his consideration. Firstly, a magazine should be published to introduce the sportsmen of the various countries who come here to participate in the Games. Our local newspapers can also do this. In this way, our athletes and sportsmen will be better prepared. Secondly, the NSPB should prepare in advance the various souvenirs, gifts, and awards depicting our national characteristics so as to give a good impression on the competitors from abroad. This is also one way to promote tourism. Thirdly, we should publicise through Radio and TV the sports events. In this way, we can inform our people better. At the same time we should prepare our athletes well so that they can win laurels for our country in the Games.

2.45 p.m.

    Mr P. Govindaswamy (Anson): Mr Speaker, Sir, the formation of the National Sports Promotion Board a few years ago by the Ministry of Social Affairs is commendable. As a result, I believe officials from the various sports organisations have organised themselves to promote sports in the Republic. We should be proud that the SEAP games will be held in Singapore very soon. We have provided many facilities to promote sports in the various fields. However, I am a little perturbed over the standard of our sportsmen in international competitions. I wonder what the Ministry is doing to inject new blood into the various fields of sports. It is no use spending so much money in providing facilities when the people are not taking advantage of them. Sportsmen do not directly contribute to the Republic's revenue. Nevertheless, their achievement abroad is a morale booster for our country. We have introduced family planning and one of the reasons is to achieve quality in our society. Therefore, sports as a social benefit should never be neglected.

    I would urge the Minister to inject new blood into our sports organisations. In this way we can bring the standard of our sports to international level.

Column: 817

Every encouragement should be given to our sportsmen, otherwise it will be very hard for them to reach a high standard. This can be accomplished to a great extent by offering incentives to our sportsmen, such as time-off and allowances. For example, a man may want to go for football practice, but he may not do so because he has to work the whole day. The result is that he would not be able to play football well. He might not be able even to kick the ball! They should also be given training in international events.

    Steps should also be taken to ensure that discipline is maintained among our sportsmen. Sometime ago the National Sports Promotion Board took action to suspend some prominent soccer players for their bad conduct abroad. I wonder whether precautionary measures have also been taken to prevent a recurrence of this nature among all other sportsmen.

    Sir, the inter-constituency tournament in soccer and basket-ball has to a certain extent provided a change of scene for our sportsmen from the various constituencies. A few talented sportsmen were selected to represent the State. I wonder whether competition of this nature can be organised for the other sports.

    Dr Tan Eng Liang (River Valley): Mr Speaker, Sir, since I will be speaking on the National Sports Promotion Board under subhead 2027 of Head 1001, for which I have an amendment* , may I be allowed to speak now? If so, I will withdraw my amendment when it comes up.
* The amendment, standing in the names of Dr Tan Eng Liang and Tuan Haji Mohd. Ariff Bin Suradi, reads as follows:

    (6) That the sum to be allocated for Head 1001 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 2027.


    The Chairman: Yes.

    Dr Tan Eng Liang: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member for Sembawang has initiated some observation on the role of the National Sports Promotion Board. I would like to add some of my own observations.

Column: 818



    Sir, the National Sports Promotion Board was officially formed on 1st February, 1971, with the primary objective of promoting all sports in the Republic. Besides encouraging, developing and promoting sports for competition and recreational purposes, the Board is also supposed to foster research and studies in sports, physical education and to train instructors. However, I regret to suggest that since its inception the Board has not achieved its prime objective.

    Many in the sporting fields have observed and complained that the NSPB has been obviously biased towards soccer. In this respect, I would like to ask the Minister for Social Affairs how much money the NSPB has spent in promoting soccer as compared to the other sports. I was surprised to learn from many members of the sporting public that the NSPB is often referred to as the "National Soccer Promotion Board."

    Despite this partial approach in favour of' the Football Association of Singapore, the standard of soccer in our Republic has still some way to go, as told to me by many a previous expert. Another interesting feature is that a scratch team is often called the Singapore Selection team or the Singapore Invitation team. It was only about a fortnight ago that I read in the newspapers that a few players from the paying spectators were requested, just before the match began, to represent Singapore in a soccer match against a foreign team. I think the Republic's name should be treated with greater respect.

    The soccer team also appears to be the privileged national team in regard to overseas travelling. The team had made about eight trips abroad during the past year, although the Association has little money. I was told that seven officials accompanied the team of only 17 footballers to participate in the

Column: 819

King's Cup tournament at Thailand. Of these seven officials, five were paid for by the NSPB.

    I heard also from the Sports Parade programme last Friday that the National Soccer Team will make an extensive tour of Australia sometime in October/November this year after the SEAP Games. This is arranged as an incentive or reward to perform well in the coming Games. I would therefore suggest that NSPB should look into the probability of arranging such trips or "rewards" for other games, which 1 am sure may perform much better than the soccer team in the coming SEAP Games!

    In this connection, some officials of the NSPB have seized every opportunity to travel abroad for no apparent good reason. Selection of officials to lead and travel with certain national teams is seldom based on merit and necessity. I would therefore suggest that available public funds must be spent wisely and fairly.

    Allow me now, Sir, to shift the scene back to Sports House - the headquarters of the NSPB. The Medical Unit, I understand, consists of a well-equipped Sports Medical Department as well as a Physiotherapy sub-unit. I would also like to know how much money was spent to set up this Unit? How many cases were treated for 1972, and whether any research papers were produced to help our various coaches and athletes? I was also told that the medical officer spends much more time trying to promote sports than conducting research in sports medicine. In addition, the physiotherapist has resigned due to the lack of work.

    Another point, Mr Speaker, Sir, that I would like to raise concerns the indiscriminate promotion of inter-constituency games, which was also previously mentioned by the other Members. While the good objective of such promotion is welcomed by all, proper and efficient planning should be exercised. The NSPB should not get involved in organising age-group games. This group of students is well catered

Column: 820

for by the schools themselves. Hence, this exercise by NSPB is a duplication of effort and taxes the young students to maximum capacity. Our national need is to look after the school leavers and to provide healthy sporting activities for their well-being. The Board can therefore spend its time more profitably if it seriously looks into this problem.

    From the above few observations, Sir, it appears that the administration of the NSPB is indeed lacking in efficiency. There is completely no co-ordination and rapport among the various sections and there appears to be also a lack of experienced officials. I would therefore suggest that the whole administration of the NSPB he thoroughly reorganised.

    It is heartening to note that the Board has received much financial aid from the commercial sector, and that for 1971 alone the Board received a grant of $400,000 from Singapore Pools (Private) Ltd. These contributions and grants from well-wishers are meant to promote sports in general and not to be so biasly confined to certain sports. Perhaps the Finance Committee of the NSPB should spend more time looking into a fairer way of apportioning funds, and should meet more regularly to effect better control of expenditure and funds.

    Tuan Haji Mohd. Ariff Bin Suradi (Kampung Kembangan)(In Malay): Mr Speaker, Sir, the suggestion made by the National Sports Promotion Board to organise inter-constituency soccer tournament with the object of promoting sports and scouting talent in sports is a good one. This will increase the standard of soccer in Singapore, which seems to be on the decline. But, Sir, you will be disheartened to learn that at this moment only 16 constituencies have organised sports clubs which have since been registered. Nine clubs are under consideration for registration, but the rest have not submitted their applications for registration. Although the effort of the NSPB is a good one, nevertheless more than 50 per cent of the constituencies have not

Column: 821

yet made any applications for registration. I believe there must be some reason why the constituencies have not responded to the call.

    The NSPB has so far only made suggestions, but it has made no real contribution whatsoever. For instance, in some constituencies like Kampung Kembangan, there are no facilities for the training of badminton, especially those with talent. The open badminton courts in the community centres are not suitable for players with talent. These players need to be trained in indoor courts because badminton competitions, whether national or international, are played in indoor courts. But I think the NSPB can at least make a useful contribution by organising group training in badminton, and also other sports like soccer, for players who show promise. Although the NSPB is biased towards soccer, nevertheless, in my constituency there is not a single football field in which to play soccer. The public is prohibited from using the school playing fields for any sports activities. Therefore, I hope the NSPB will, in addition to organising sports at inter-constituency level, also provide facilities for the training of talented youths. For instance, there should be facilities for the training of soccer, swimming, badminton, etc.

3.00 p.m.

    Dr Ong Leong Boon (Kim Seng): Mr Speaker, Sir, may 1 join the chorus of four Members who have spoken about the somewhat sad state of affairs that exists in the sports world in Singapore today. I remember having risen here and said the same thing some six months ago, and to this day I am sad to say that there has been no visible improvement in any particular game in Singapore.

    Sir, six months ago, I called for the formation of a Sports Ministry and I have not forgotten about this call. If the NSPB, as we have heard earlier on, cannot properly carry out its functions and responsibility expected of it, then scrap it. Let us not continue to allow vast sums of money to go down the

Column: 822

"soccer drain". Soccer has risen to no heights. We hope it will rise. But despite all the efforts that have been put in, I think it still stays on a pretty low plane.

    Sir, I would like to be fair in my comment. Over the last year or so the Government has, in fact, tried to promote sports in the form of inter-constituency games, and it has definitely aroused more interest and more participation from various people -sportsmen and athletes - throughout Singapore. But I think we have to do much more than what we have done. I would like to repeat what has been said earlier by certain Members that the emphasis by the NSPB has been and still is - we hope never - lopsided. This lopsidedness is too apparent and is not in the interest of the sporting world in Singapore. Soccer has been promoted too much without any reasonable result. What about the other sports organisations? We have yet to hear of the volley ball association, for example, sending its team for competition elsewhere. We have yet to hear of the NSPB trying to promote the other sporting activities. Members may be aware that at the recent karate competition, one member of the Singapore team did very well, and nobody has suggested sending our karate team for further training in Japan. I think we should promote our national teams. Boxing requires to be further promoted. Table tennis, badminton, even swimming and water polo, need further promotion.

    In swimming, our boys and girls have been sent overseas through the main efforts of their own parents. I say swimming has done far more to uplift the standard of Singapore sports than many other games.

    An hon. Member: Hear, hear!

    Dr Ong Leong Boon: It has won us the most gold medals in the last SEAP games. And I am sure it still will. But we have not done enough. Sir, I can continue rolling on. But let me come to specifics.

    I would like to suggest to the Minister concerned that perhaps we should, at

Column: 823

least for a start, consider two matters and grant special consideration for our sportsmen. Firstly, we should give time-off to our sportsmen for their training. Let us facilitate them. Some of them might be working in Jurong, and they have to come down for training at Fairer Park. They finish work at 5 p.m. and they are expected to be at Fairer Park at 5 p.m. I say, this is a bit too much. I can quote cases where they just cannot make it. In the end, they would probably drop out of the national team.

    Secondly, I am sure the various sports associations would appreciate it if the Minister can arrange with the Singapore Airlines, just like the arrangement by the Ministry of Education for special concession rates, to send our athletes or sportsmen overseas at concession rates. The Ministry of Education has arranged group tours at half-price. Why not do the same for our sportsmen?

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Labour (Mr Fong Sip Chee): Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise to speak as I am provoked by the very sincere though very vigorous arguments put forward by the Member for Kim Seng. From the impromptu utterances in this House, one can actually sample the true feelings of the Members here. The Member for Kim Seng has put up a pretty balanced argument, although the Member for River Valley's argument might appear to be lopsided. Probably it is because he was an exponent in water polo in his younger days. I hope he still is. But I would take his argument very seriously, Sir, because I believe the Member for River Valley, as well as the Member for Kim Seng, know what they are talking about because they were sportsmen before.

    Sir, I think we in Singapore are faced with a rather difficult situation in that our population is not sufficiently sports conscious in as much as they are not sufficiently culture conscious from the arguments we heard yesterday. A solution might well appear to be to

Column: 824

broaden the sports base. The best approach would be to train our young students in the schools. It is indeed a very heartening sight nowadays, if we drive around or near the locations of the schools, to see young students sweating themselves, running along the road and unfortunately, at the same time, breathing in rather polluted air.

    Sir, we have to face the fact that our population here is of migrant stock. We carry with us a rather different thinking on matters like sports. Sir, I remember that when I was a young lad, any extra-mural activities on my part, like trying to kick a football in a back-lane, would always end up with a few strokes of the rotan at the most tender part of my body. That was unfortunately the opinion or idea of our older generation on sports. Our forefathers rather preferred us to spend more time digging into our books than going round kicking a ball, unfortunately, at the wrong place too - in a backlane. The situation has changed now. We cannot afford to have a population digging into books with total disregard for physical fitness, particularly in a highly urbanised society as in Singapore.

    Sir, I have the advantage of seeing a few highly industrialised cities in this part of the world. I find that the population there has a rather significant peculiarity in that they are small in build, fair, and rather timid in nature. I think this is due to the fact that the country is so highly urbanised that the people have got to live in small houses. There is no chance for them to stretch their muscles. The working rhythm and lack of nourishment are contributing factors. And, most important, they are not sports conscious. In that situation, I am afraid it is almost impossible to produce good sportsmen because of insufficient facilities for the promotion of sports. In the end, they produce a young generation who are small built. Sir, I mention this not with the intention of throwing any reflection on any Member in this House. I say that we have to accept what nature has given us. But I think we can improve on our physical make-up by better nourishment,

Column: 825

facilities for sports and exercise. We do not need to develop ourselves into a highly urbanised and civilized society but with soft knees and soft elbows. We may have good brains, but I think we also need the muscles and the stamina to make our brains work.

    Sir, I think the Members have put forward very positive arguments. In my younger days, I was only a second grade sportsman; I never reached the first team in the school. Probably I did not do enough. I do not wish to put the entire blame on my generation. But I feel that the Members who have spoken - I hope all Members in this House - can be equally positive, physically, in promoting sports as they are vocal on that subject in this House. I was rather impressed by the argument of the Member for Sembawang. This is a rare occasion, Sir, that I agree with him. I believe that when credit is due, it must be readily given. I was quite impressed by the rather balanced argument in the first part of his speech, but disappointed towards the end.

    Sir, when the Member for Sembawang stood up, I recall that he had also on a few occasions got himself involved or perhaps someone else involved him in some kind of sports - I do not know whichever way it was. He was the leader of the table tennis team that toured Seoul, South Korea. Am I correct? Sir, before I go on I would like to seek clarification. If it is not true, then I would divert the subject. Did the Member for Sembawang lead a table tennis team to Seoul and a swimming team to Rangoon in Burma?

    Mr Teong Eng Siong(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, this is quite irrelevant to what we are talking about.

    Mr Fong Sip Chee: Sir, I am trying to prove my point. And I hope Members can be equally active and positive in their physical actions towards sports, as they are vocal or championing the cause in this House.

    Mr Teong Eng Siong(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Parliamentary Secretary is talking rubbish!

Column: 826



    Mr Fong Sip Chee: Mr Speaker, Sir, may I seek your ruling on the last remark of the Member for Sembawang as to whether or not it is parliamentary?

    The Chairman: You are swimming very close to the danger line. Standing Order 47 (10) says:

    `No reference shall be made to the conduct or character of any Member or of any public servant, other than his conduct in his capacity as a Member or as a public servant.'

    Mr Fong Sip Chee: Sir, I am just trying to seek clarification. That is the lead for me to develop my argument. I do not know why the Member for Sembawang is so self-conscious. Probably he suspects that my argument would be leading in such a way that it is not in his favour. Sir, I think that is prejudging. It may be a bouquet for him. May I be allowed to carry on?

    The Chairman: Mr Fong, are you making remarks about him as a Member of Parliament?

    Mr Fong Sip Chee: Yes, Sir,It is a bouquet for him.

    The Chairman: Are you praising him?

    Mr Fong Sip Chee: Sir, whichever way you want to interpret it, I think I will leave it to your ruling.

    The Chairman: I would rather you stop referring to the hon. Member for Sembawang, and carry on with your speech.

    Mr Fong Sip Chee: Very well, Sir, if it pleases you, I will put it this way. May I in doing so repeat what I have in my mind earlier, and that is, that Members should be active and positive in their approach towards this subject physically rather than merely making utterances in this House. I believe it is of no use if some Members of Parliament headed some sports associations. I know one Member, Sir, who is involved with the Boxing Association and this Association is doing well. They produce good boxers. But I cannot see the logic that a certain Member of Parliament led teams of, say, table tennis and swimming overseas, when he

Column: 827

himself did not in the first place contribute much to deserve those trips. Secondly, what were the experiences of these two trips?

3.15 p.m.
